columns.text: In this problem, we will determine the amount of gains or losses for every price change in the given scenario.

We can recall that a put option is the contract wherein the buyer of the option has the option to sell products at a specified price. This option is exercised if the current market price is lower than the previous price. 

On the other hand, a call option is the contract wherein the buyer of the call option, has the choice to buy a product at a certain price. This option is exercised if the current market price is higher than the previous price.

Given that the price of oil is $\$52.00$ per barrel, then the call option payoff will be **zero** since it is illogical to exercise this option if it is lower than the exercise price of $\$57.00$

We can then solve for the payoff for the put option by multiplying the quantity to be purchased to the difference between the strike price and current price. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Put option payoff}&=\text{quantity} \times\text{(strike price-current price)}\\
&=50,000 \times(\$57.00-\$52.00)\\
&=50,000 \times \$5.00\\
&=\$250,000.00
\end{aligned}$$

To get the total gain/loss, we will subtract the Put option payoff by the Call option pay off:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total profit/loss}&=\$250,000.00-0\\
&=\$250,000.00
\end{aligned}$$

The total profit for this transaction is $\$250,000.00$

To get the total gain/loss, we will subtract the Put option payoff by the Call option pay off:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total profit/loss}&=\$100,000.00-0\\
&=\$100,000.00
\end{aligned}$$

The total profit for this transaction is $\$100,000.00$

If the price of oil is $\$55.00$ per barrel, then the call option payoff will be **zero** since it is illogical to exercise this option if it is lower than the exercise price of $\$57.00$

For the put option, we can use the formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Put option payoff}&=\text{quantity} \times\text{(strike price-current price)}\\
&=50,000 \times(\$57.00-\$55.00)\\
&=50,000 \times \$2.00\\
&=\$100,000.00
\end{aligned}$$

If the price of oil is $\$57.00$ per barrel, then the call option payoff will be **zero** since it is illogical to exercise this option if it is lower than or equal to  the exercise price of $\$57.00$

For the put option,  it is illogical to exercise this option if it is higher than or equal to  the exercise price of $\$57.00$. Therefore, the value is also **zero**

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total profit/loss}&=0\\
\end{aligned}$$

There is no profit nor loss in this transaction

If the price of oil is $\$59$ per barrel, then the call option payoff will be: 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Call option payoff}&=\text{quantity} \times\text{(current price - strike price)}\\
&=50,000 \times(\$59-\$57)\\
&=50,000 \times \$2\\
&=\$100,000
\end{aligned}$$

For the put option,  it is illogical to exercise this option if it is higher than or equal to  the exercise price of $\$57.00$. Therefore, the value is **zero**

To get the total gain/loss, we will subtract the two values:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total profit/loss}&=\$100,000.00-0\\
&=\$100,000.00
\end{aligned}$$

The total profit for this transaction is $\$100,000.00$

If the price of oil is $\$62$ per barrel, then the call option payoff will be: 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Call option payoff}&=\text{quantity} \times\text{(current price - strike price)}\\
&=50,000 \times(\$62-\$57)\\
&=50,000 \times \$5\\
&=\$250,000
\end{aligned}$$

For the put option,  it is illogical to exercise this option if it is higher than or equal to  the exercise price of $\$57.00$. Therefore, the value is **zero**

To get the total gain/loss, we will subtract the two values:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total profit/loss}&=\$250,000-0\\
&=\$100,000.00
\end{aligned}$$

The total profit for this transaction is $\$250,000$
As we can see from the computations, a profit can only be earned if the current market price and the strike price are not the same since one option will cancel out the other option.
